units.title: Introduce iTracer vector into iPSCs
units.text: The lineage recorder is based on the Sleeping Beauty transposon system, which enables efficient transposition of exogenous DNA into multiple genomic loci within iPSCs. A poly-adenylated green or red fluorescent protein (GFP or RFP) reporter is driven by the RPBSA promoter and contains a barcode (11 nucleotides of random bases) in the 3′ untranslated region, which serves as the first channel of the recorder. In the opposite direction, 91 bases away from the RPBSA promoter, we have introduced a human U6 promoter driving a guide RNA (gRNA) that targets a region in the 3′ portion of the sequence coding for GFP or RFP. This iTracer construct is introduced by electroporation into iPSCs that contain a doxycycline-inducible Cas9 cassette (iCRISPR).
units.rationale: This describes a clear, actionable protocol step for introducing the iTracer genetic construct into iPSCs using electroporation.

units.title: Induce Cas9-mediated scarring with doxycycline
units.text: Fluorescent cells containing the reporter can be isolated using flow cytometry before being propagated or cryopreserved for later use. From these uniquely barcoded iPSCs, we initiate cerebral organoids using approximately 2,000 cells to record lineages during organoid development (Fig. 1b). At a time point of choice, doxycycline introduction into the medium induces Cas9 expression in organoid cells, followed by formation of Cas9–gRNA complexes, leading to double-stranded break formation at the targeted location in the fluorescent reporter region of the recorder.
units.rationale: This outlines a precise, time-controlled experimental step to induce genomic scarring via doxycycline-triggered Cas9 activity.

units.title: Optimize doxycycline concentration and duration for scarring
units.text: We found scarring was most efficient when samples were incubated with 8 µg ml−1 doxycycline for 24 h and applied these conditions in all subsequent experiments.
units.rationale: This provides a specific, optimized protocol parameter for inducing Cas9-mediated scarring with defined concentration and duration.

units.title: Initiate cerebral organoids from barcoded iPSCs
units.text: From these uniquely barcoded iPSCs, we initiate cerebral organoids using approximately 2,000 cells to record lineages during organoid development (Fig. 1b).
units.rationale: This specifies the exact cell number and starting material for organoid initiation, a critical procedural step.

units.title: Perform scRNA-seq on organoid cells
units.text: We measured barcode diversity using scRNA-seq data from three iTracer iPSC pools and found approximately 60,000 unique sequences (Methods). We followed barcode diversity throughout organoid development using targeted amplicon sequencing of the barcode region (Extended Data Fig. 1b,c) and found relatively stable diversity over the course of organoid development from pluripotency (Extended Data Fig. 1c).
units.rationale: This describes the use of scRNA-seq and targeted sequencing as a protocol to track barcode diversity during organoid development.

units.title: Analyze barcode and scar families via UMAP and permutation enrichment
units.text: We first focused on barcodes, which mark clones derived from one given cell in the initializing EB, and explored the clonality of transcriptionally distinct organoid cell clusters. We performed a permutation enrichment analysis using single cells from all lineage-traced organoids together to determine the likelihood that barcode families were shared between cell clusters (Fig. 1g and Extended Data Fig. 4a,b).
units.rationale: This details a specific analytical protocol to assess clonal enrichment across cell clusters using permutation testing.

units.title: Isolate fluorescent reporter-expressing cells via flow cytometry
units.text: Fluorescent cells containing the reporter can be isolated using flow cytometry before being propagated or cryopreserved for later use.
units.rationale: This is a clear, actionable step for selecting and isolating successfully transfected iPSCs prior to organoid formation.
